Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Brain Metabolic Plasticity and Agression
Award.AbstractNarration: This research project will address the fundamental, but complex biological phenomenon of the link between brain function and behavior. The brain is an integrated and dynamic system with regions, neuronal tracts, and cell types that show distinct responses to environmental stimuli, and these responses must be integrated to coordinate behavioral response. In this project, the mechanisms underlying aggressive behavior in honey bees will be analyzed. It is known that metabolism is integral to the aggression in honey bees, however, the consequences of the aggression-related shift in metabolism, in terms of neural and behavioral plasticity, remain unknown. The Project will combine the modeling tools of systems biology with genomic data and experimental validation to address the link between brain metabolism and behavior in the context of aggressive behavior in the honey bee. The Price Lab will construct a genome-scale metabolic network model for the honey bee, which will provide a framework to hypothesize how changes in metabolic gene expression affect metabolism in the honey bee brain. In addition, they will analyze genetic and regulatory variation between sub-species of honey bee to identify candidate regulators of brain metabolism. Identifying genetic variation in the regulators of brain metabolism may provide insight into whether natural variation in aggression is a result of heritable differences in metabolic regulation in the brain. The combined modeling and experimental aspects of this project offer a multitude of opportunities for students to take part in independent research and learn new modeling and experimental techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this project, we have evaluated evidence that natural variation in aggressive behavior is associated with a shift toward aerobic glycolysis in the brain of the honey bee (Apis mellifera). We reanalyzed microarray data and took new metabolomics measurements to evaluate the possibility that decreased OXPhos in the aggressive brain may be more accurately described as a shift toward aerobic glycolysis. We hypothesized that this metabolic state, which is associated with altered neurotransmitter levels, increased glycolytically derived ATP and a reduced cellular redox state, may lead to increased neuronal excitability and oxidative stress in the brain. Our analysis provided evidence for a robust, distinct and persistent brain metabolic response to aggression-inducing social cues. Our findings, presented in a manuscript published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal (Chandrsekaran et al, 2015. Genes, Brains & Behavior 14, 158), associated aerobic glycolysis with naturally occurring behavioral plasticity.

Secondly, we have reconstructed a genome-scale metabolic model for the bee brain from knowledge of the bee genome and the biochemical reactions associated with metabolism. To construct this metabolic network for honeybee, we used public resources and databases to identify sets of relevant metabolic pathways. The model was then made tissue-specific for the bee brain, based on existing transcriptomic data as well as data collected as part of this project. Our model was used to run simulations for the identification of functional implications of aerobic glycolysis in the aggressive bee brain. Our metabolic model was then integrated with gene expression data, provided by our collaborators in Illinois, in order to determine key regulators of metabolism in honey bee aggression profiles. We have focused primarily on evaluating aggression related metabolic changes as observed in extensive transcriptional data that we have from experimental measurements. We are using the metabolic reconstruction of the honey bee to interpret these changes. Our results demonstrate the upregulated aerobic glycolysis and downregulated oxidative phosphorylation phenotype as a descriptor of aggressive behavior in honey bees, which was part of the original motivation for this proposal. Our results will be presented in a manuscript published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal, which is currently under final stages of preparation.

A third goal has been to publish our textbook on Systems Biology (with co-authors Lee Hood, Ilya Shmulevich and Sui Huang). The book is a major undertaking and currently under final rounds of revisions. Most of the chapters of the book have undergone external editing, and are being passed onto the publisher for the next round. Our belief is that our book will be a widely used text for advanced undergraduate students, and for early graduate and medical students. The hope is to broadly catalyze educational experiences in this field for a broad range of students interested in the field of Systems Biology.

The project also supported opportunities for training and professional development in our laboratory. A graduate student and two research scientists were supported consecutively during their time in our lab. The project also gave us the opportunity to train two undergraduate interns through the ISB summer internship program.
